data.title: Drawing SpriteFonts to multiple RenderTarget2Ds consecutively leads to all but the first render target missing the text (WindowsGL)
data.body:
https://github.com/bwfox/RenderTargetBug

![rendertargetbug](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4255552/578224/5f721f50-c84e-11e2-8120-fbfed901f7c1.png)

The top window in the image is using MonoGame using the WindowsGL, the bottom XNA. I believe the problem occurs under the MacOSX build. 

The program produces a series of RenderTarget2Ds featuring text drawn using SpriteFont. These render targets are then drawn onto the backbuffer (with each subsequent render target being vertically offset from the previous). The first render target drawn to displays as expected but subsequent render targets are missing text, instead displaying empty boxes rather than the expected glyphs.

Switching the font being used by DrawString will lead to the next render target to be drawn to correctly but any following attempts with that font will fail, unless you switch to drawing with another font first.

(the red text can be ignored, they're just two strings drawn to the backbuffer, one before the render targets are drawn and one after.)

data.title: OpenTK based versions of MonoGame will not allow you to change DepthStencilFormat
data.body:
Setting GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredDepthStencilFormat seems to have no effect in WindowsGL and OSX versions of MonoGame. The result is that you are stuck with whatever size of Depth and Stencil buffer you are given, even if the graphics hardware supports a larger buffer. 

I tweaked one of the samples to demonstrate the problem here, but it should be fairly easy to reproduce:
https://github.com/bwfox/MonoGameDepthBufferBug

When the DepthFormat is set to 16 bits in the Graphics3DSampleGame() constructor, the rendered models should produce noticeable z-fighting along the seam where they meet. 

I have pull the latest code from the develop branch (including the fix for Issue #1739 ). The state of PresentationParameters on the graphics device reflects the DepthFormat assignment, but the rendered result does not.

data.title: Vertex buffer size is declared incorrectly for PSM in VertexBuffer.cs
data.body:
While trying to load an FBX model for PSM studio I'm getting array size inconsistencies.

I've traced the root cause down to line 352 / 353 in VertexBuffer.cs

The _vertexArray size is being initialised without taking into account the size of the type of data in the array.

Currently is is initialised with

_vertexArray = new T[VertexCount];

but this just creates an array the size of VertexCount, where it should be VertexCount \* size in bytes of Type T

When the Array.Copy tries to populate the array it is not large enough to hold the data being copied and crashes.

data.title: PreparingDeviceSettings is not called in MonoGame
data.body: This event is not invoked from GraphicsDeviceManager before the graphics device is created. XNA does this to allow you to affect the presentation parameters of the device.

data.title: Fix for clearing of forground framebuffer when un-setting RenderTargets.
data.body:
This fixes an ongoing problem with some of our Transitions.  What was happening is that our background graphics were being cleared.

Draw a graphic and then using a RenderTarget we would draw over that graphic.  During the unsetting of the RenderTarget it looks like the foreground framebuffer is being cleared.  

This now works like the XNA implementation.

Tested on Android, iOS and Mac.

data.title: For consideration - MonoGame.Portable
data.body:
This is a PCL variant of the MonoGame framework, effectively another platform.

The allows the full MonoGame framework to be used as a reference to PCL libraries for development purposes.

This allows a PCL project to host the majority (if not all in most cases) game code within a PCL library.  When combined with a platform version of MonoGame this allows the game to be run from the PCL project using that platforms implementation of MonoGame.

Note, although this PR has updated several classes, the only thing that has been added are #IF precompilers to ignore incompatible code whilst is is being accessed from a PCL project.

Have tested all other platform builds with the new precompilers added with no downturn effect.

data.title: Multi-Window Input Handling
data.body:
So like a month ago we submitted a PR to expose the ability to create more than one GameWindow in a Game.

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1465

While this is all working rendering wise just fine...  we now have to deal with input handling.  In particular there are two problem areas:
1. TouchPanel
2. Mouse.GetState()

With both they share the same problem...  touch positions and mouse positions are both relative to the window origin.  Since we have multiple windows...   who is to say what GameWindow the touch/mouse is in?

The first solution I was thinking about is something like this:

```
var touchState1 = TouchPanel.GetState(); // The primary Game.Window
var touchState2 = SecondGameWindow.TouchPanel.GetState();
```

The idea being GameWindow would have a getter to access the correct TouchPanel state for each window.  The global `TouchPanel.GetState()` would be unchanged...  it would just always be the state from the primary GameWindow.

Now I don't know if that exactly fits with mouse input.  The same technique could work:

```
var mouseState1 = Mouse.GetState(); // The primary Game.Window
var mouseState2 = SecondGameWindow.Mouse.GetState();
```

Just not sure what happens when the mouse is not actively in one of the windows.  I guess the same as if the mouse is outside of the primary GameWindow in a single window game?

Anyway...  I've put up this issue to solicit ideas before we submit a PR to add the functionality.  Please give us feedback!

data.title: Add DebuggerHidden attribute to CheckGLError
data.body: The DebuggerHidden attribute makes the debugger break at the caller of CheckGLError if an exception is thrown, not inside CheckGLError.  This is much more helpful to devs as they do not have to manually navigate up the callstack.
